posts.cooked:
I just got off the phone with a family member that was trying to transfer their Signal account to a new phone. We ended up spending an hour and a half of going back and forth, changing phone numbers and reinstalling the app multiple times, all because the family member accidentally hit the wrong button at startup.

signal-2022-11-14-235050_002922×2048 90.8 KB

As you can see in the screenshot above, the ‘Transfer or restore account’ button isn’t really a button at all. It’s a tiny bit of text that could easily be mistaken for some descriptive text. So when the family member opened Signal on the new phone, they just assumed that ‘Continue’ was the logical next thing to do when opening the app. So they then entered their phone number and the verification code autofilled, meaning that the account was now on the new phone with none of the chat history.

We ended up spending a lot of time trying to figure out how to initiate the phone-to-phone transfer. In the end, we figured it out, but after a lot of trouble.

Admittedly, I should have been more clear about which buttons to press, but when Signal’s startup page opens with one giant blue button, it’s just natural to click that one.

I think things would be a lot more clear for the average user if the ‘Transfer or restore account’ button looked similar to the ‘Continue’ button. That way there’s no way to miss it. In fact, what would be even better is if the ‘Continue’ button was changed to make it obvious that you then can’t do a phone-to-phone transfer. That way there would be no confusion.

Note that the iOS screen shared above is actually shown after you go through confirming your phone number (and registration lock if necessary). Initially, Signal iOS shows a similar interface to Android with the single “Continue” button (without “Transfer or restore account” / “Transfer account”).

Additional off-topic details

Though on iPads there is a small button on that initial screen to switch to registering as a primary device instead of linking.

The server tells the app that transferring may be possible based on the “transfer” account capability that the old device has set.

Also confirmed by the aforementioned blog post (emphasis mine):

  1. After verifying your phone number on the new device, tap the prompt asking if you would like to transfer your account and message history from another iOS device.

posts.cooked:
Whenever I see a safety number change from a contact, I ask them whether they knew of the account transfer feature of Signal. Almost always, they did not.

Recently, one indicated that he ‘must have missed’ the text ‘Transfer or restore account’ on the initial Signal screen after installation on a new phone.

Reviewing this screen, the emphasis of this option is the same as that of ‘Terms & Privacy Policy’, which people naturally skip over.

The lack of emphasis on transferring an account between phones results in a poor UX post-re-registation, lacking all chat history and removing verifications for the user, and imposes upon others a poor UX when they’re prompted whether to send messages to this user within group chats due to a safety number change.

The UI design of this screen could be greatly improved by making the ‘Transfer or restore account’ a button itself, with close to or equal weight to the ‘Continue’ button. Further, this could be made more clear of a flow by renaming these something like ‘New to Signal?’ and ‘I’m an existing user’.

transfer1024×2275 94.7 KB

I absolutely agree, at a minimum I think the buttons should have equal weight. Considering how often people change their phones nowadays, we should give as much focus and support to existing normal “non-power” users (who might not realize, until they get the shock of going into the app after setting it up on their new phone, that their existing chat history wasn’t automatically transferred with the regular Apple/Samsung device transfer procedure).

So I like your idea of having buttons saying something like “I’m a new Signal user” and “I’m an existing user” to make it crystal clear for each type of user what they’re supposed to tap (with the additional benefit of not confusing new users, which I can only assume is why the ‘transfer’ option was deemphasized on that screen).

The Signal team spent a lot of effort adding the ability to transfer one’s account and messages over! The ability to do that should be properly advertised to existing users. Otherwise, they might get annoyed enough that they’re apt to jump ship to some other non-private, but no-brainer message-preserving app.

After making mistakes for several times I noticed that there is actually a restore button and that is the text below ‘Continue’.
I too was deceived easily.

Exactly they need to make the transfer or restore button more obvious using a border like the ‘Continue’ button (that has blue background) or something else.
For reference let me mention that WhatsApp has red background for ‘restore’

Make the 'Transfer or restore account' button more obvious during first-time setup UI/UX Feedback
Ouch, that almost looks like those dark patterns that discourage you from rejecting cookies .

I support the theory that Signal doesn’t want to encourage people using backups in the current form.

QuickBanana:

I support the theory that Signal doesn’t want to encourage people using backups in the current form.

But that not valid for the transfer method (which is included in this button for Android) because that is quite modern and comfortable - even if it might take ages . It’s not a good design choice anyway.

ProrokFyodorov:

Whenever I see a safety number change from a contact, I ask them whether they knew of the account transfer feature of Signal. Almost always, they did not.

Recently, one indicated that he ‘must have missed’ the text ‘Transfer or restore account’ on the initial Signal screen after installation on a new phone.

This is happening at least every week amongst my contacts. A simple redesign on this screen, perhaps with more explanatory text (‘Keep all of your chats by transferring your existing account’), could prevent this really poor and aggrivating UX (for both the user and their contacts).

ProrokFyodorov:

A simple redesign on this screen

Heck, I think even “redesign” is too strong of a word. Change “Transfer or restore account” into a proper button, move it above “Continue”, and change “Continue” to instead say “I’m a new user”. Those changes would be so simple, yet would help so many people immeasurably.

I understand that the Signal team has a lot on their plate. And that this might not seem very high priority. And that they likely have procedures where they have to call a meeting (or several) to make any changes even as small as this (and that obviously a dev/designer wouldn’t be allowed to just go in and make this change themselves on their own). Such protocols obviously are in place to prevent making rash decisions/changes on things. But I think in something like this case, where a couple very small changes can have a huge impact, the all-or-nothingness of a full “redesign”, ends up having the effect of making the tremendously-great-right-now (which can always be improved upon later) into an enemy of the “perfect”.
